Only use strategy when it’s necessary. For example, if livecheck is already using Git for a URL, it’s not necessary to use strategy :git. However, if Git applies to a URL but we need to use PageMatch, it’s necessary to use strategy :page_match.

Only use the GithubLatest strategy when it’s necessary and correct. Github.com rate limits requests and we try to minimize our use of this strategy to avoid hitting the rate limit on CI or when using brew livecheck --tap on large taps (e.g. homebrew/core). The Git strategy is often sufficient and we only need to use GithubLatest when the “latest” release is different than the newest version from the tags.

Regexes should be made case insensitive, whenever possible, by adding i at the end (e.g. /.../i or %r{...}i). This improves reliability, as the regex will handle changes in letter case without needing modifications.

Regexes should only use a capturing group around the version text. For example, in /href=.*?example-v?(\d+(?:\.\d+)+)(?:-src)?\.t/i, we’re only using a capturing group around the version test (matching a version like 1.2, 1.2.3, etc.) and we’re using non-capturing groups elsewhere (e.g. (?:-src)?).
Regional, Localized: Any version that isn’t the US English one, when that exists.

Research available sources to select a URL. Try removing the file name from stable/url, to see if this is a directory listing page. If that doesn’t work, try to find a page that links to the file (e.g. a download page). If it’s not possible to find the newest version on the website, try checking other sources from the formula/cask. When necessary, search for other sources outside of the formula/cask.
Run brew update twice and brew doctor (and fix all the warnings) before creating an issue!

trans-unit.source: Trial: Time-limited version that stops working entirely after it expires, requiring payment to lift the limitation.
Unofficial: An allegedly unmodified compiled binary, by a third-party, of a binary that has no existing build by the owner of the source code.

Use [._-] in place of a period/underscore/hyphen between the software name and version in a file name. For a file named example-1.2.3.tar.gz, example[._-]v?(\d+(?:\.\d+)+)\.t will continue matching if the upstream file name format changes to example_1.2.3.tar.gz or example.1.2.3.tar.gz.

Use \.t in place of \.tgz, \.tar\.gz, etc. There are a variety of different file extensions for tarballs (e.g. .tar.bz2, tbz2, .tar.gz, .tgz, .tar.xz, .txz, etc.) and the upstream source may switch from one compression format to another over time. \.t avoids this issue by matching current and future formats starting with t. Outside of tarballs, we use the full file extension in the regex like \.zip, \.jar, etc.
Use the debug output to understand the situation. brew livecheck --debug <formula>|<cask> provides information about which URLs livecheck tries, any strategies that apply, matched versions, etc.
Vendorless: A binary distributed without an official website, like a forum posting.

A tap is Homebrew-speak for a Git repository containing extra formulae. Homebrew has the capability to add (and remove) multiple taps to your local installation with the brew tap and brew untap commands. Type man brew in your terminal. The main repository at https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core, often called homebrew/core, is always built-in.

A formula is a package definition written in Ruby. It can be created with brew create <URL> where <URL> is a zip or tarball, installed with brew install <formula>, and debugged with brew install --debug --verbose <formula>. Formulae use the Formula API which provides various Homebrew-specific helpers.
trans-unit.target: Una fórmula es una definición de paquete escrita en Ruby. Se puede crear con brew create <URL> donde <URL> es un zip o tarball, se puede instalar con brew install <formula> y se puede depurar con brew install --debug --verbose <formula> . Las fórmulas utilizan la API de fórmulas, que proporciona varios ayudantes específicos de Homebrew.

trans-unit.source: A Homebrew analytics user ID, e.g. 1BAB65CC-FE7F-4D8C-AB45-B7DB5A6BA9CB. This is generated by uuidgen and stored in the repository-specific Git configuration variable homebrew.analyticsuuid within $(brew --repository)/.git/config. This does not allow us to track individual users, but does enable us to accurately measure user counts versus event counts. The ID is specific to the Homebrew package manager, and does not permit Homebrew maintainers to e.g. track you across websites you visit.

A Homebrew analytics user ID, e.g. 1BAB65CC-FE7F-4D8C-AB45-B7DB5A6BA9CB. This is generated by uuidgen and stored in the repository-specific Git configuration variable homebrew.analyticsuuid within $(brew --repository)/.git/config. This does not allow us to track individual users but does enable us to accurately measure user counts vs. event counts (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/protocol/v1/parameters#cid)

Esto lo genera uuidgen y se almacena en la variable de configuración de Git específica del repositorio homebrew.analyticsuuid dentro de $(brew --repository)/.git/config Git / config . Esto no nos permite realizar un seguimiento de los usuarios individuales, pero nos permite medir con precisión los recuentos de usuarios frente a los recuentos de eventos (https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/protocol/v1/parameters#cid)

trans-unit.source: Additional commands, including external commands, can of course be written to provide more detailed information. There are a couple of disadvantages here. First, it means writing Ruby against a possibly changing Homebrew codebase. There will be more code to touch during refactors, and Homebrew can’t guarantee that external commands will continue to work. Second, it means designing the commands themselves, specifying input parameters and output formats.
trans-unit.target: Por supuesto, se pueden escribir comandos adicionales, incluidos comandos externos, para proporcionar información más detallada. Aquí hay un par de desventajas. Primero, significa escribir Ruby contra un código base de Homebrew posiblemente cambiante. Habrá más código para tocar durante las refacciones, y Homebrew no puede garantizar que los comandos externos sigan funcionando. En segundo lugar, significa diseñar los propios comandos, especificando parámetros de entrada y formatos de salida.

trans-unit.source: Also note that such a formula would only be compatible with the same Node major version it originally was compiled with. This means that we need to revision every formula with a Node native addon with every major version bump of the node formula. Para asegurarse de que no pasemos por alto su fórmula en un aumento de la versión principal de Nodo, escriba una prueba significativa que fallaría en tal caso (invocada con una versión de Nodo incompatible con ABI).

trans-unit.source: An executable script for a command named extcmd should be named brew-extcmd. The script itself can use any suitable shebang (#!) line, so an external script can be written in Bash, Ruby, or even Python. Unlike the ruby commands this file must not end with a language-specific suffix (.sh, or .py). This file will be run via exec with some Homebrew variables set as environment variables, and passed any additional command-line arguments.
trans-unit.target: Un script ejecutable para un comando llamado extcmd debería llamarse brew-extcmd . El script en sí puede usar cualquier línea shebang ( #! ) Adecuada, por lo que un script externo se puede escribir en Bash, Ruby o incluso Python. A diferencia de los comandos de ruby, este archivo no debe terminar con un sufijo específico del idioma ( .sh o .py ). Este archivo se ejecutará a través de exec con algunas variables de Homebrew configuradas como variables de entorno y pasará cualquier argumento adicional de línea de comandos.

trans-unit.source: An external command extcmd implemented as a Ruby command should be named brew-extcmd.rb. The command is executed by doing a require on the full pathname. As the command is required, it has full access to the Homebrew “environment”, i.e. all global variables and modules that any internal command has access to. Be wary of using Homebrew internals; they may change at any time without warning.
trans-unit.target: Un comando externo extcmd implementado como un comando de Ruby debe llamarse brew-extcmd.rb . El comando se ejecuta haciendo un require en el nombre de ruta completo. Como se require el comando d, tiene acceso completo al “entorno” de Homebrew, es decir, todas las variables y módulos globales a los que cualquier comando interno tiene acceso. Tenga cuidado con el uso de componentes internos de Homebrew; pueden cambiar en cualquier momento sin previo aviso.

trans-unit.source: Another example would be configuration files that should not be overwritten on package upgrades. If after installation you find that to-be-persisted configuration files are not copied but instead symlinked into /usr/local/etc/ from the Cellar, this can often be rectified by passing an appropriate argument to the package’s configure script. That argument will vary depending on a given package’s configure script and/or Makefile, but one example might be: --sysconfdir=#{etc}

Ese argumento variará según el script de configuración de un paquete determinado y / o Makefile, pero un ejemplo podría ser: --sysconfdir=#{etc}

As Homebrew became primarily a binary package manager, most users were fulfilling Requirements with the default_formula, not with arbitrary alternatives. To improve quality and reduce variation, Homebrew now exclusively supports using the default formula, as an ordinary dependency, and no longer supports using arbitrary alternatives.

Para mejorar la calidad y reducir la variación, Homebrew ahora admite exclusivamente el uso de la fórmula predeterminada, como una dependencia ordinaria, y ya no admite el uso de alternativas arbitrarias.

trans-unit.source: At Homebrew, we like to put the name of the formula up front like so: foobar 7.3 (new formula). This may seem crazy short, but you’ll find that forcing yourself to summarise the commit encourages you to be atomic and concise. If you can’t summarise it in 50-80 characters, you’re probably trying to commit two commits as one. For a more thorough explanation, please read Tim Pope’s excellent blog post, A Note About Git Commit Messages.
trans-unit.target: En Homebrew, nos gusta poner el nombre de la fórmula al foobar 7.3 (new formula) así: foobar 7.3 (nueva fórmula) . Esto puede parecer una locura, pero descubrirás que obligarte a resumir el compromiso te anima a ser atómico y conciso. Si no puede resumirlo en 50-80 caracteres, probablemente esté intentando confirmar dos confirmaciones como una. Para obtener una explicación más detallada, lea la excelente publicación del blog de Tim Pope, Una nota sobre los mensajes de confirmación de Git .

trans-unit.source: Bottles are created using the Brew Test Bot, usually when people submit pull requests to Homebrew. The bottle do block is updated by maintainers when they merge a pull request. For the Homebrew organisations’ taps they are uploaded to and downloaded from Bintray.

Bottles are created using the Brew Test Bot. This happens mostly when people submit pull requests to Homebrew and the bottle do block is updated by maintainers when they brew pull --bottle the contents of a pull request. For the Homebrew organisations’ taps they are uploaded to and downloaded from Bintray.
trans-unit.target: Las botellas se crean utilizando Brew Test Bot . Esto sucede principalmente cuando las personas envían solicitudes de extracción a Homebrew y los brew pull --bottle mantenimiento actualizan el bloque de bottle do cuando elaboran extracción: embotellan el contenido de una solicitud de extracción. Para los grifos de las organizaciones Homebrew, se cargan y descargan de Bintray .

trans-unit.source: Bottles are produced by installing a formula with brew install --build-bottle <formula> and then bottling it with brew bottle <formula>. This outputs the bottle DSL which should be inserted into the formula file.
trans-unit.target: Las botellas se producen instalando una fórmula con brew install --build-bottle <formula> y luego embotellada con brew bottle <formula> . Esto genera la botella DSL que debe insertarse en el archivo de fórmula.

trans-unit.source: Bottles are simple gzipped tarballs of compiled binaries. Any metadata is stored in a formula’s bottle DSL and in the bottle filename (i.e. macOS version, revision).
trans-unit.target: Las botellas son simples tarball comprimidos con gzip de binarios compilados. Todos los metadatos se almacenan en el DSL de la botella de una fórmula y en el nombre de archivo de la botella (es decir, versión de macOS, revisión).

trans-unit.source: Bottles have a DSL to be used in formulae which is contained in the bottle do ... end block.
trans-unit.target: Las botellas tienen un DSL para ser utilizado en fórmulas que está contenida en el bloque bottle do ... end block.

trans-unit.source: Bottles will not be used if the user requests it (see above), if the formula requests it (with pour_bottle?), if any options are specified during installation (bottles are all compiled with default options), if the bottle is not up to date (e.g. lacking a checksum) or if the bottle’s cellar is not :any nor equal to the current HOMEBREW_CELLAR.
trans-unit.target: Las botellas no se utilizarán si el usuario lo solicita (ver arriba), si la fórmula lo solicita (con pour_bottle? ), Si se especifica alguna opción durante la instalación (todas las botellas se compilan con las opciones predeterminadas), si la botella no está a la altura fecha (por ejemplo, sin suma de verificación) o si la cellar la botella no es :any ni igual a la HOMEBREW_CELLAR actual .

By default packages that require BLAS/LAPACK linear algebra interfaces should link to OpenBLAS using depends_on "openblas" and passing -DBLA_VENDOR=OpenBLAS to CMake (applies to CMake based formula only) rather than Apple’s Accelerate framework, or the default reference lapack implementation. Apple’s implementation of BLAS/LAPACK is outdated and may introduce hard-to-debug problems. The reference lapack formula is fine, although it is not actively maintained or tuned. For this reason, formulae needing BLAS/LAPACK should link with OpenBLAS.
trans-unit.target: De forma predeterminada, los paquetes que requieren interfaces de álgebra lineal BLAS / LAPACK deben vincularse a OpenBLAS usando depends_on "openblas" y pasando -DBLA_VENDOR=OpenBLAS a CMake (se aplica solo a la fórmula basada en CMake) en lugar del marco Accelerate de Apple, o la implementación de lapack de referencia predeterminada. La implementación de BLAS / LAPACK de Apple está desactualizada y puede presentar problemas difíciles de depurar. La fórmula de referencia de lapack está bien, aunque no se mantiene o ajusta activamente. Por esta razón, las fórmulas que necesitan BLAS / LAPACK deben vincularse con OpenBLAS.

trans-unit.source: By default, brew release will bump the patch version number. Pass --major or --minor to bump the major or minor version numbers, respectively. The command will fail if the previous major or minor release was made less than one month ago.

trans-unit.source: By default, bottles will be built for the oldest CPU supported by the OS/architecture you’re building for (Core 2 for 64-bit OSs). This ensures that bottles are compatible with all computers you might distribute them to. If you really want your bottles to be optimised for something else, you can pass the --bottle-arch= option to build for another architecture; for example, brew install foo --build-bottle --bottle-arch=penryn. Just remember that if you build for a newer architecture some of your users might get binaries they can’t run and that would be sad!

This ensures that bottles are compatible with all computers you might distribute them to. If you really want your bottles to be optimized for something else, you can pass the --bottle-arch= option to build for another architecture; for example, brew install foo --build-bottle --bottle-arch=penryn. Just remember that if you build for a newer architecture some of your users might get binaries they can’t run and that would be sad!

trans-unit.source: Casks can also be installed from a tap. Casks can be included in taps with formulae, or in a tap with just casks. Place any cask files you wish to make available in a Casks directory at the top level of your tap.

Casks which do not reach a minimum notability threshold (see Rejected Casks) aren’t accepted in the main repositories because the increased maintenance burden doesn’t justify the poor usage numbers they will likely get. This notability check is performed automatically by the audit commands we provide, but its decisions aren’t set in stone. A cask which fails the notability check can be added if it is:

Casks which use version :latest are also excluded, because we have no way to track the version they’re in. It helps to ask the developers of such software to provide versioned releases (i.e. have the version in the path of the download url).

trans-unit.source: Detailed explanation about why we use Method Signatures and its syntax can be found here. The only extra thing to keep in mind is that we add method signatures to RBI files instead of the actual method definition in the code. This way we preserve the original code structure and everything related to Sorbet is kept within the Library/Homebrew/sorbet directory.

Detecting whether a setup.py uses setup() from setuptools or distutils is difficult, but we always need to pass this flag to setuptools-based scripts. pip faces the same problem that we do and forces setup() to use the setuptools version by loading a shim around setup.py that imports setuptools before doing anything else. Since setuptools monkey-patches distutils and replaces its setup function, this provides a single, consistent interface. We have borrowed this code and use it in Language::Python.setup_install_args.
trans-unit.target: Detectar si un setup.py usa setup() de setuptools o distutils es difícil, pero siempre debemos pasar este indicador a los scripts basados ​​en setuptools. pip enfrenta el mismo problema que nosotros y obliga a setup() a usar la versión de setuptools cargando un shim alrededor de setup.py que importa setuptools antes de hacer cualquier otra cosa. Dado que setuptools monkey-patches distutils y reemplaza su función de setup , esto proporciona una interfaz única y consistente. Hemos tomado prestado este código y lo usamos en Language::Python.setup_install_args .

Distribute (not to be confused with distutils) is an obsolete fork of setuptools. Distlib is a package maintained outside the standard library which is used by pip for some low-level packaging operations and is not relevant to most setup.py users.
trans-unit.target: Distribute (no confundir con distutils) es una bifurcación obsoleta de setuptools. Distlib es un paquete que se mantiene fuera de la biblioteca estándar que pip utiliza para algunas operaciones de empaquetado de bajo nivel y no es relevante para la mayoría de los usuarios de setup.py .

trans-unit.source: Distutils and pip use a “flat” installation hierarchy that installs modules as individual files under site-packages while easy_install installs zipped eggs to site-packages instead.
trans-unit.target: Distutils y pip utilizan una jerarquía de instalación "plana" que instala módulos como archivos individuales en paquetes de sitio, mientras que easy_install instala huevos comprimidos en paquetes de sitio.

trans-unit.source: Distutils is a module in the Python standard library that provides developers a basic package management API. Setuptools is a module distributed outside the standard library that extends distutils. It is a convention that Python packages provide a setup.py that calls the setup() function from either distutils or setuptools.
trans-unit.target: Distutils es un módulo de la biblioteca estándar de Python que proporciona a los desarrolladores una API básica de administración de paquetes. Setuptools es un módulo distribuido fuera de la biblioteca estándar que extiende distutils. Es una convención que los paquetes de Python proporcionan un setup.py que llama a la función setup() desde distutils o setuptools.

Every Ruby file in the codebase has a magic # typed: <level> comment at the top, where <level> is one of Sorbet’s strictness levels, usually false, true or strict. The false files only report errors related to the syntax, constant resolution and correctness of the method signatures, but no type errors. Our long-term goal is to move all false files to true and start reporting type errors on those files as well. Therefore, when adding new files, you should ideally mark it with # typed: true and work out any resulting type errors.

Every Ruby file in the codebase is divided into three strictness levels: false, true and strict. The false files only report errors related to the syntax, constant resolution and correctness of the method signatures, and not type errors. We use this file to override strictness on a file-by-file basis. Our longtime goal is to move all false files to true and start reporting type errors on those files as well. If you are making changes that require adding a new ruby file, we would urge you to add it to true and work out the resulting type errors. Read more about Sorbet’s strictness levels here.

Firstly, the overall environment in which Homebrew runs is filtered to avoid environment contamination breaking from-source builds (https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/issues/932). In particular, this process filters all but the given whitelisted variables, but allows environment variables prefixed with HOMEBREW_. The specific implementation can be seen in bin/brew.

Firstly, the overall environment in which Homebrew runs is filtered to avoid environment contamination breaking from-source builds (https://github.com/Homebrew/brew/issues/932). trans-unit.source: Formula requiring MPI should use OpenMPI by adding depends_on "open-mpi" to the formula, rather than MPICH. These packages have conflicts and provide the same standardised interfaces. Choosing a default implementation and requiring it to be adopted allows software to link against multiple libraries that rely on MPI without creating un-anticipated incompatibilities due to differing MPI runtimes.

Formula requiring MPI should use OpenMPI by adding depends_on "open-mpi" to the formula, rather than MPICH. These packages have conflicts and provide the same standardized interfaces. Choosing a default implementation and requiring it to be adopted allows software to link against multiple libraries that rely on MPI without creating un-anticipated incompatibilities due to differing MPI runtimes.
trans-unit.target: La fórmula que requiere MPI debe usar OpenMPI agregando depends_on "open-mpi" a la fórmula, en lugar de MPICH . Estos paquetes tienen conflictos y proporcionan las mismas interfaces estandarizadas. La elección de una implementación predeterminada y su adopción permite que el software se vincule con varias bibliotecas que dependen de MPI sin crear incompatibilidades inesperadas debido a los diferentes tiempos de ejecución de MPI.

GUI apps on macOS don’t have /usr/local/bin in their PATH by default. If you’re on Mountain Lion or later, you can fix this by running sudo launchctl config user path "/usr/local/bin:$PATH" and then rebooting, as documented in man launchctl. Note that this sets the launchctl PATH for all users. For earlier versions of macOS, see this page.

trans-unit.source: Give your issue a descriptive title which includes the formula name (if applicable) and the version of macOS or Linux you are using. For example, if a formula fails to build, title your issue “<formula> failed to build on <10.x>”, where “<formula>” is the name of the formula that failed to build, and “<10.x>” is the version of macOS or Linux you are using.
trans-unit.target: Asigne a su problema un título descriptivo que incluya el nombre de la fórmula (si corresponde) y la versión de macOS o Linux que está utilizando. Por ejemplo, si una fórmula no se construye, titule su problema “<fórmula> no se pudo construir sobre <10.x>”, donde “<fórmula>” es el nombre de la fórmula que no se pudo construir y “<10. x> ”es la versión de macOS o Linux que está utilizando.

trans-unit.source: Giving style and usage feedback on a PR or commit that involves documents is okay and encouraged. But keep in mind that these are just guidelines, and for any change, the author may have made a deliberate choice to break these rules in the interest of understandability or aesthetics.
trans-unit.target: Dar información sobre el estilo y el uso de las relaciones públicas o de los compromisos que implican documentos está bien y se anima a hacerlo.Pero tenga en cuenta que estas son sólo pautas,y para cualquier cambio,el autor puede haber hecho una elección deliberada para romper estas reglas en interés de la comprensión o la estética.

trans-unit.source: Go to the relevant repository (e.g. https://github.com/Homebrew/brew, https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core, etc.) and create a pull request to request review and merging of the commits in your pushed branch. Explain why the change is needed and, if fixing a bug, how to reproduce the bug. Make sure you have done each step in the checklist that appears in your new PR.
trans-unit.target: Vaya al repositorio relevante (por ejemplo , https://github.com/Homebrew/brew , https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core , etc.) y cree una solicitud de extracción para solicitar la revisión y fusión de las confirmaciones en tu rama empujada. Explique por qué es necesario el cambio y, si se corrige un error, cómo reproducirlo. Asegúrese de haber realizado todos los pasos de la lista de verificación que aparece en su nuevo RP.

Homebrew build environment that uses years-battle-hardened build logic to help your ./configure && make && make install and even your gem install succeed. Especially handy if you run Homebrew in an Xcode-only configuration since it adds tools like make to your PATH which build systems would not find otherwise.

Homebrew can run on 32-bit ARM (Raspberry Pi and others) and 64-bit ARM (AArch64), but no binary packages (bottles) are available. Support for ARM is on a best-effort basis. Pull requests are welcome to improve the experience on ARM platforms.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew comes with a number of standard test fixtures, including numerous sample images, sounds, and documents in various formats. You can get the file path to a test fixture with test_fixtures("test.svg").
Homebrew comes with completion definitions for the brew command. Some packages also provide completion definitions for their own programs.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew viene con definiciones de finalización para el comando brew . Algunos paquetes también proporcionan definiciones de finalización para sus propios programas.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew depends on having an up-to-date version of Xcode because it comes with specific versions of build tools, e.g. clang.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew depende de tener una versión actualizada de Xcode porque viene con versiones específicas de herramientas de compilación, por ejemplo, clang .

trans-unit.source: Homebrew depends on having an up-to-date version of Xcode because it comes with specific versions of build tools, e.g. clang. Installing a custom version of GCC or Autotools into your PATH has the potential to break lots of compiles so we prefer the Apple or Homebrew-provided compilers. Cross-compilers based on GCC will typically be “keg-only” and therefore not linked into your PATH by default, or are prefixed with the target architecture, again to avoid conflicting with Apple or Homebrew compilers.

Homebrew does not currently support 32-bit x86 platforms. It would be possible for Homebrew to work on 32-bit x86 platforms with some effort. An interested and dedicated person could maintain a fork of Homebrew to develop support for 32-bit x86.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew no soporta actualmente las plataformas x86 de 32 bits.Sería posible que Homebrew trabajara en plataformas x86 de 32 bits con algún esfuerzo.Una persona interesada y dedicada podría mantener una bifurcación de Homebrew para desarrollar el soporte para x86 de 32 bits.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew doesn’t package already-packaged language-specific libraries. These should be installed directly from gem/cpan/pip etc.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew no empaqueta bibliotecas específicas de idiomas ya empaquetadas. Deben instalarse directamente desde gem / cpan / pip , etc.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew doesn’t support arbitrary mixing and matching of formula versions, so everything a formula depends on, and everything that depends on it in turn, needs to be upgraded to the latest version as that’s the only combination of formulae we test. As a consequence any given upgrade or install command can upgrade many other (seemingly unrelated) formulae, if something important like python or openssl also needed an upgrade.

Homebrew draws a distinction between Python applications and Python libraries. The difference is that users generally do not care that applications are written in Python; it is unusual that a user would expect to be able to import foo after installing an application. Examples of applications are ansible and jrnl.

Homebrew draws a distinction between Python applications and Python libraries. Examples of applications are ansible and jrnl.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew establece una distinción entre las aplicaciones de Python y las bibliotecas de Python . trans-unit.source: Homebrew formulae should avoid having multiple, separate, upstream projects bundled together in a single package to avoid shipping outdated/insecure versions of software that is already a formula.

Homebrew gathers anonymous aggregate user behaviour analytics using Google Analytics. You will be notified the first time you run brew update or install Homebrew. Analytics are not enabled until after this notice is shown, to ensure that you can opt out without ever sending analytics data.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew has since stopped supporting SHA1 and MD5 entirely. MD5 checksums were removed from core formulae in 2012 and as of April 2015 installing a formula verified by MD5 is actively blocked.

Homebrew’s pre-built binary packages (known as bottles) of many packages can only be used if you install in the default installation prefix, otherwise they have to be built from source. Building from source takes a long time, is prone to fail, and is not supported. Do yourself a favour and install to the default prefix so that you can use our pre-built binary packages. The default prefix is /usr/local for macOS on Intel, /opt/homebrew for macOS on ARM, and /home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew for Linux. Pick another prefix at your peril!

Homebrew’s versions are not intended to be used for any old versions you personally require for your project. You should create your own tap for formulae you or your organisation wish to control the versioning of or those that do not meet the above standards. Software that has regular API or ABI breaking releases still needs to meet all the above requirements; that a brew upgrade has broken something for you is not an argument for us to add and maintain a formula for you.
trans-unit.target: Las versiones de Homebrew no están diseñadas para usarse con versiones antiguas que usted personalmente necesite para su proyecto. Debe crear su propio grifo para las fórmulas que usted o su organización desean controlar o aquellas que no cumplen con los estándares anteriores. El software que tiene versiones de última hora regulares de API o ABI aún debe cumplir con todos los requisitos anteriores; que una brew upgrade haya roto algo para usted no es un argumento para que agreguemos y mantengamos una fórmula para usted.

trans-unit.source: Homebrew’s versions should not be used to “pin” formulae to your personal requirements. You should instead create your own tap for formulae you or your organisation wish to control the versioning of, or those that do not meet the above standards. Software that has regular API or ABI breaking releases still needs to meet all the above requirements; that a brew upgrade has broken something for you is not an argument for us to add and maintain a formula for you.

Homebrew, like git(1), supports external commands. These are executable scripts that reside somewhere in the PATH, named brew-cmdname or brew-cmdname.rb, which can be invoked like brewcmdname. This allows you to create your own commands without modifying Homebrew’s internals.
trans-unit.target: Homebrew, como git (1), admite comandos externos. Estos son scripts ejecutables que residen en algún lugar de la PATH , denominados brew- cmdname o brew- cmdname .rb , que se pueden invocar como brew cmdname . Esto le permite crear sus propios comandos sin modificar los componentes internos de Homebrew.

If an app that bundles malware was not signed with an Apple Developer ID and you purposefully disabled or bypassed Gatekeeper, no action will be taken on our part. When you disable security features, you do so at your own risk. If, however, an app that bundles malware is signed, Apple can revoke its permissions and it will no longer run on the computers of users that keep security features on — we all benefit, Homebrew Cask users or not. To report a signed app that bundles malware, use Apple’s Feedback Assistant

If set, brew update only lists updates to installed software.
If set, always assume --debug when running commands.
If set, always assume --verbose when running commands.
If set, always use Homebrew’s vendored, relocatable Ruby version even if the system version of Ruby is new enough.

If set, always use a Homebrew-installed git(1) rather than the system version. Automatically set if the system version of git is too old.
If set, always use the latest stable tag (even if developer commands have been run).
If set, disable all use of legacy compatibility code.
If set, do not automatically update before running brew install, brew upgrade or brew tap.
If set, do not automatically update before running some commands e.g. brew install, brew upgrade and brew tap.
If set, do not check for broken dependents after installing, upgrading or reinstalling formulae.

If set, do not print HOMEBREW_INSTALL_BADGE on a successful build.
If set, do not print text with colour added.

If set, do not use Bootsnap to speed up repeated brew calls.
If set, do not use the GitHub API, e.g. for searches or fetching relevant issues after a failed install.
If set, enable runtime typechecking using Sorbet.
If set, fail on the failure of installation from a bottle rather than falling back to building from source.
If set, forbid redirects from secure HTTPS to insecure HTTP.
If set, force colour output on non-TTY outputs.
If set, pass --verbose when invoking curl(1).
If set, pass the -A option when calling sudo(8).
If set, print install times for each formula at the end of the run.
If set, refuse to load formulae. This is useful when formulae are not trusted (such as in pull requests).
If set, running Homebrew on Linux will use URLs for macOS. This is useful when merging pull requests for macOS while on Linux.
If set, tweak behaviour to be more relevant for Homebrew developers (active or budding) by e.g. turning warnings into errors.
If set, use bat for the brew cat command.
If set, use Bootsnap to speed up repeated brew calls. A no-op when using Homebrew’s vendored, relocatable Ruby on macOS (as it doesn’t work).
If set, use Pry for the brew irb command.
If set, verbose output will print a . no more than once a minute. This can be useful to avoid long-running Homebrew commands being killed due to no output.

trans-unit.source: If the Node module is also available on the npm registry, we prefer npm hosted release tarballs over GitHub (or elsewhere) hosted source tarballs. The advantages of these tarballs are that they don’t include the files from the .npmignore (such as tests) resulting in a smaller download size and that any possible transpilation step is already done (e.g. no need to compile CoffeeScript files as a build step).

trans-unit.source: If there is a formula that currently exists in the Homebrew/homebrew-core repository or has existed in the past (i.e. was migrated or deleted), you can recover it for your own use with the brew extract command. This will copy the desired version of the formula into a custom tap. For example, if your project depends on automake 1.12 instead of the most recent version, you can obtain the automake formula at version 1.12 by running brew extract automake <YOUR_GITHUB_USER>/<YOUR_TAP_REPOSITORY_NAME> --version=1.12. Formulae obtained this way may contain deprecated, disabled or removed Homebrew syntax (e.g. checksums may be sha1 instead of sha256); the brew extract command does not edit or update formulae to meet current standards and style requirements.
trans-unit.target: Si hay una fórmula que existe actualmente en el repositorio Homebrew / homebrew-core o ha existido en el pasado (es decir, fue migrada o eliminada), puede recuperarla para su propio uso con el comando brew extract . Esto copiará la versión deseada de la fórmula en un grifo personalizado. Por ejemplo, si su proyecto depende de automake 1.12 en lugar de la versión más reciente, puede obtener la fórmula de automake en la versión 1.12 ejecutando brew extract automake <YOUR_GITHUB_USER>/<YOUR_TAP_REPOSITORY_NAME> --version=1.12 . Las fórmulas obtenidas de esta manera pueden contener sintaxis Homebrew obsoleta, desactivada o eliminada (por ejemplo, las sumas de comprobación pueden ser sha1 en lugar de sha256 ); el brew extract El comando no edita ni actualiza fórmulas para cumplir con los estándares y requisitos de estilo actuales.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to build against custom non-Homebrew dependencies that are provided by Homebrew (e.g. a non-Homebrew, non-macOS ruby) then you must create and maintain your own tap as these formulae will not be accepted in Homebrew/homebrew-core. Once you have done that you can specify env :std in the formula which will allow e.g. which ruby to access your existing PATH variable and allow compilation to link against this Ruby. You can also include a custom Requirement in your formula that more accurately describes the non-Homebrew software you build against.

trans-unit.source: If your formulae have the same name as Homebrew/homebrew-core formulae they cannot be installed side-by-side. If you wish to create a different version of a formula that’s in Homebrew/homebrew-core (e.g. with options) consider giving it a different name e.g. nginx-full for more fully-featured nginx formula. This will allow both nginx and nginx-full to be installed at the same time (assuming one is keg_only or the linked files do not clash).

If your formulae have the same name as Homebrew/homebrew-core formulae they cannot be installed side-by-side. If you wish to create a different version of a formula that’s in Homebrew/homebrew-core (e.g. with options) consider giving it a different name e.g. nginx-full for more fully-featured nginx formula. This will allow both nginx and nginx-full to be installed at the same time (but not linked if there are conflicts and one of them is not declared to be keg_only).
trans-unit.target: Si sus fórmulas tienen el mismo nombre que las fórmulas Homebrew / homebrew-core, no se pueden instalar una al lado de la otra. Esto permitirá que tanto nginx como nginx-full se instalen al mismo tiempo (pero no vinculados si hay conflictos y uno de ellos no está declarado como keg_only ).

Libraries may be installed to libexec and added to sys.path by writing a .pth file (named like “homebrew-foo.pth”) to the prefix site-packages. This simplifies the ensuing drama if pip is accidentally used to upgrade a Homebrew-installed package and prevents the accumulation of stale .pyc files in Homebrew’s site-packages.
trans-unit.target: Las bibliotecas se pueden instalar en libexec y agregar a sys.path escribiendo un archivo .pth (llamado como “homebrew-foo.pth”) en el prefix site-packages. Esto simplifica el drama resultante si pip se usa accidentalmente para actualizar un paquete instalado por Homebrew y evita la acumulación de archivos .pyc obsoletos en los paquetes del sitio de Homebrew.
